statement: Does every convex polygon have a vertex with no other 4 vertices equidistant from it? Equivalently: for every convex polygon P with vertices v_1, ..., v_n, does there exist a vertex v_i such that no four other vertices v_a, v_b, v_c, v_d satisfy d(v_i, v_a) = d(v_i, v_b) = d(v_i, v_c) = d(v_i, v_d)?
win_condition: Find a convex polygon with n vertices such that EVERY vertex has at least 4 other vertices equidistant from it. That is, for every vertex v_i, there exist distinct vertices v_a, v_b, v_c, v_d (all different from v_i) with d(v_i, v_a) = d(v_i, v_b) = d(v_i, v_c) = d(v_i, v_d).
background: Erdős posed this problem in 1946. The weaker version with 3 equidistant vertices (instead of 4) was disproved by Danzer, who constructed a 9-point convex polygon where every vertex has 3 equidistant vertices. Fishburn and Reeds later found a 20-point convex polygon with a similar uniform equidistance property. Erdős asserted that Danzer proved the statement false for any constant k (not just k=3), but this claim was not repeated in later publications, suggesting possible error. The convexity requirement is essential: without it, counterexamples exist using unit-distance graph embeddings. The problem is connected to Erdős Problem 96: if true for k+1 vertices, it would establish an upper bound of kn for Problem 96 via induction. The problem carries a $100 bounty.
known_bounds: Danzer's 9-point construction achieves 3 equidistant vertices per vertex (k=3). Fishburn-Reeds 20-point construction also achieves uniform equidistance. No construction achieving k=4 (every vertex having 4 equidistant vertices) in convex position is known. The regular n-gon gives at most 2 equidistant vertices per vertex for any given distance (due to chord-length uniqueness).

strategy_suggestions.suggestion: Study and extend Danzer's 9-point construction for k=3 to achieve k=4
strategy_suggestions.rationale: Danzer's construction is the only known example achieving uniform equidistance in convex position. Understanding its algebraic structure may reveal how to add vertices or modify the construction to achieve 4 equidistant vertices per vertex.

strategy_suggestions.suggestion: Search among cyclic polygons (all vertices on a single circle)
strategy_suggestions.rationale: Points on a circle are automatically in convex position. Equal distances correspond to equal chord lengths, i.e. equal angular separations. The problem reduces to finding a set of angles on [0, 2π) such that every angle has 4 others at equal angular difference. This connects to difference sets and additive combinatorics.

strategy_suggestions.suggestion: Search among points on two concentric circles (extending the approach from Erdős Problem 1082)
strategy_suggestions.rationale: Two-layer cyclic constructions provide richer distance spectra than single-circle constructions while keeping the parameter space low-dimensional. Cross-layer distances add new coincidence opportunities.

strategy_suggestions.suggestion: Use algebraic/optimization approach: parameterize convex n-gons and optimize for equidistance coverage
strategy_suggestions.rationale: Define an objective function counting the minimum over vertices of the maximum multiplicity of distances from that vertex, and maximize it. Use gradient-free optimization (simulated annealing) on vertex coordinates with convexity constraint.

prior_attempts.description: Danzer's construction of a 9-point convex polygon with uniform 3-equidistance
prior_attempts.result: Successfully achieves k=3 (every vertex has 3 equidistant vertices) but not k=4
prior_attempts.what_was_ruled_out: This specific construction does not extend trivially to k=4

prior_attempts.description: Fishburn-Reeds 20-point convex polygon with uniform equidistance property
prior_attempts.result: Achieves uniform equidistance but specific k value and construction details should be investigated
prior_attempts.what_was_ruled_out: Details of construction needed to assess extensibility

search_constraints.constraint: Focus on n <= 100 vertices for initial screening
search_constraints.rationale: Smaller polygons are easier to verify exactly and the known constructions use 9-20 vertices

search_constraints.constraint: Ensure strict convexity of all candidate polygons
search_constraints.rationale: The problem specifically requires convex polygons; non-convex counterexamples are known to exist

search_constraints.constraint: Use exact arithmetic or high-precision (200+ digits) for distance comparisons
search_constraints.rationale: Near-equal distances in floating-point can give false positives; exact verification is essential
